11.title: Branding guidelines

12.title: Select a school
12.content:
Design System > Patterns
      Select a school
      A pattern for selecting a school from the list of all schools in England
    
  



  

Help users to select a school from a list of all schools in England.



When to use this pattern

Use this pattern if you need to ask users to select one or more schools in England.

When not to use this pattern

Do not use this pattern if you can get the information in another way, for example by linking users with an existing account.

Do not use this pattern if asking users which schools they attended, and they may have attended school a long time ago or outside of England. Instead, use a regular text field.

How it works

The pattern uses an autocomplete. This allows users to search for a school using its name or a reference number, and then select a school from a list of matching results.

If javascript is available the results are shown as the user types, in a list below the text input. If javascript is not available, the results are shown on a separate page after the user presses a search button.

Data source

You can get a list of all schools in England (around 50,000) from the Get information about schools service.

You can either download this data periodically and update the list in your service, or use their API to fetch updated data as a daily task.

Using school references

There are many different unique references for schools, including:


Unique Reference Number (URN) – from the Edubase service
UK Provider Reference Number (UKPRN) - from the UK register of learning providers
LAESTAB number
Postcode of the school address


You should research with the users of your service to see which references they may be familiar with. If one or more reference is comonly used, you can support this within your autocomplete to save users time and help avoid errors.

Disambiguating schools

Lots of schools in England have the exact same name. To help users select the right school, display some information alongside the name.

Depending on your service, you could choose to show:


postcode
city or town
a reference number


Filtering by type of school

Depending on the needs of your service, you could filter the list of all schools to reduce the number of false matches.

You could filter the list by:


phase, for example primary, secondary
school funding type
removing schools that have closed
including or excluding multi-academy trusts (MATs)


Research on this pattern

This pattern has been used successfully by many services.

Services using this pattern

Lots of services from the Department for Education are using a variant of this pattern, including:


Schools financial benchmarking
Find school and college performance data in England
Register trainee teachers
Publish teacher training courses
Get help buying for schools


Help improve this pattern

Contribute to this guidance to help improve the pattern for others.

15.title: Design criteria
15.content:
Design System >  Components 
      Design criteria
      Use the 4 stage acceptance criteria to validate if building a new component is the right thing to do.
    
  



  
    When designing a new service, always start with what is available already. 
    Check the GOV.UK Design System (opens in new tab) before designing anything new because those patterns and components have already been researched and tested to make sure they’re accessible.
    If you design anything new, your team will have to do all of the user research and accessibility testing and audit (opens in new tab) work to make sure that it is meeting the needs of your users and the accessibility standards.
    You can also consider if there are components from design systems from other government departments (opens in new tab) that can support meeting your user needs. 
    Four stage acceptance criteria
    This does not stop new components being created, but instead, puts checks in place to prevent over-engineering of service frontends.
    
      
        
          Can the problem be solved with existing components or patterns?
          The primary look and feel for digital services is the GOV.UK Frontend (opens in new tab) with available components, patterns and styles detailed in the GOV.UK Design System (opens in new tab).
          Where appropriate, contributions should be made back to the design system to support the development of components for other users. 
          The GOV.UK Design System backlog (opens in new tab) also contains components which are being considered, are in development, or have been built by other designers. 
          If you decide the problem cannot be designed around by anything that exists in the design system, and it is a common problem, ask in DfE or Gov Digital Slack channels to see if anyone else has designed for the same problem. 
          - interaction-design (DfE Slack)
          - developers (DfE Slack)
          - design (GOV Digital Slack) 
          - govuk-design-system (GOV Digital Slack)
        
        
          Does it meet user needs across multiple services?
          Designers can often work in silos and as a result aren’t aware of what other DfE designers are working on. This becomes obvious and a pain point for users of multiple DfE services, which have been designed and built by different teams. 
          Using components consistently, sharing with other designers and understanding who the users are and which services they use, helps to provide a consistent experience of DfE services and will help you meet the following standards: 
          
          -  Service Standard 3 - provide a joined up experience across all channels (opens in new tab) 
          
          -  WCAG 3.2.4 (AA) - Consistent identification (opens in new tab)
          
        
        
          Does it add value to the user experience?
          When designing a new component, you should ensure it meets a validated user need through user research. Designing components and features which meet user’s needs, should be shared so that other designers can use them in their services. 
          
          Components and features should not be built or designed just to make something look aesthetically pleasing, but instead add value, solve a problem or make something complex, understandable.
          
        
        
          Is it accessible?
          Accessibility is non-negotiable. If you are assessed on your service, and it is not accessible, you will get a Not Met outcome.
          New components or features must meet the component design guidelines and be able to be used by people of all abilities. 
          
          When considering a new component, it will often go through several iterations and design decisions will be made on what to take forward and what to discard, often through design crits, show and tells and user research.
          
          Involving a wide range of people in these decisions will ensure you are being inclusive in your design approach. 
          
          You can read the full guidance for accessibility acceptance criteria for components on GOV.UK (opens in new tab)
          
        
      
    
  
  
    
    Related information
    
      
        Designing for different browsers and devices
      
      
        GOV.UK Frontend coding standards

17.title: Publishing content on GOV.UK
17.content:
Content guidelines
      Publishing content on GOV.UK
      DfE’s GOV.UK content is managed by the Digital Communication Team (DCT).
    
  

Work with DCT on GOV.UK content
Contact DCT if you:


need to update GOV.UK content or add a start page as part of your service
are going to request a GOV.UK exemption or campaign site from the Government Digital Service (GDS)
have identified a user need for an information (non-transactional) service

You can find out how to contact and work with DCT (opens intranet page in new tab) on the DfE intranet. If you do not have access to the IT Service Portal, ask a civil servant to raise the ticket for you. You can be added to the ticket after it has been raised.
Creating new information services
If you identify a user need for an information (non-transactional) service, raise an advice ticket on the IT Service Portal first (opens intranet page in new tab), to discuss if this need can be met on GOV.UK. If you do not have access to the IT Service Portal, ask a civil servant to raise the ticket for you. You can be added to the ticket after it has been raised.
Campaign sites
Campaign sites usually act as a landing page for other communication activity. They can carry images and branding and allow you to direct people to guidance on GOV.UK and elsewhere.
Contact Clare Arolker at Clare.Arolker@education.gov.uk or Indira Periera-Lopes at Indira.Periera-Lopes@education.gov.uk if you think that a single page campaign site (opens in new tab) will best meet your user’s needs.
For campaign sites, DCT will:


provide advice and guidance on your application
submit your request to GDS
give ‘Head of Digital’ approval, this is provided by Owen Roffe as this is a communications lead product rather than a digital service

Requesting GOV.UK website and domain exemptions
All requests for GOV.UK website and domain exemptions (opens in new tab) should be reviewed by DCT before being submitted to GDS.
Contact Clare Arolker at Clare.Arolker@education.gov.uk or Indira Periera-Lopes at Indira.Periera-Lopes@education.gov.uk before submitting your application so that they have enough time to review it.
DCT reviews all applications so that:


they’re aware of ongoing projects
GOV.UK has been properly considered before your request is submitted to GDS
they can support you if you need to publish new content on GOV.UK as part of your exemption request

If you do not have access to the IT Service Portal, ask a civil servant to raise the ticket for you. You can be added to the ticket after it has been raised.
DCT can also support you if you need an exemption.

A
Agile
Agile is a project management methodology which focuses on delivering value and outcomes to users quicker than traditional waterfall approaches.
Instead of delivering everything in one go, features are delivered iterativley by teams working on focused tasks to deliver an outcome.
Read the Agile Manifesto (opens in new tab)
Agile delivery on GOV.UK Service Manual (opens in new tab)
Alpha
A phase in the delivery lifecycle which is after Discovery and before Beta.
In the alpha phase, you’re expected to test your riskiest assumptions, build prototypes, try different solutions to solve your problems to meet you user needs.
You may also have a service assessment before the end of your alpha phase.
B
Beta
A phase in the delivery lifecycle which is after Alpha and before Live.
Beta may be split into Private Beta and Public Beta.
C
D
Discovery
A phase in the delivery lifecycle which is the first phase and before Alpha.
E
F
G
H
I
J
K
L
Live
A phase in the delivery lifecycle which is the final phase and after Beta.
M
MVP
MVP is an acronym for Minimum Viable Product. This is used to describe a service with meets the minimum requirements of a user need.
It is often used to describe the first release or iteration of a service.
N
O
P
Private Beta
A phase in Beta where testing of a service is carried out with a closed group of users.
This allows service teams to work with the users to better understand any problems and get targeted feedback. It also allows teams to understand service performance without being overwhelmed with users.
Public Beta
A phase in Beta where testing of a service is unrestricted to users.
Q
R
S
T
U
User need
User needs are the needs that a user has of a service, and which that service must satisfy for the user to get the right outcome for them.
Lean about users and their needs (opens in new tab)

20.title: Joining user journeys between GOV.UK and digital services
20.content:
Content guidelines
    Joining user journeys between GOV.UK and digital services
    To ensure a joined up journey for users between GOV.UK and DfE digital services, content designers work closely with the Digital Communications Team (DCT). The DCT create, publish and manage DfE’s content on GOV.UK.
    
  

Designing content for GOV.UK
When working with the DCT on DfE digital services, content designers:


must work with the DCT (opens intranet page in new tab) on any GOV.UK content. If you do not have access to the DfE intranet, ask a colleague with access to get the information for you
must prototype a version of any content as a minimum viable product (MVP) for non-transactional services on GOV.UK using Whitehall publisher (opens in new tab), the GOV.UK content management system
should map out journeys for services to show a user’s journey

Working in this way is part of how DfE content designers meet point 3 of the Service Standard to provide a joined up experience across all channels (opens in new tab).
Request a Whitehall publisher account
You will need a Whitehall publisher account to publish content on GOV.UK.
You can request access to Whitehall publisher training or accounts by raising a request with DCT (opens intranet page in new tab). If you’re a contractor you should ask a civil servant to make this request for you.
Providing a joined up experience across all channels
GOV.UK is a central publishing platform with services attached to it. Most users start their journey by reading some information before entering into a digital service. Content designers working on different parts of a journey should think about joined up services as users understand them, instead of as isolated transactions.
At DfE, DCT content designers generally work on GOV.UK content. Content designers working on a digital service that joins up to GOV.UK should work with DCT.
DCT use Whitehall publisher to manage DfE’s GOV.UK content. Other DfE content designers may be given access to Whitehall but they should follow the DfE GOV.UK content management process (opens intranet page in new tab) and work with them to publish any GOV.UK content.
Examples of joined up journeys between GOV.UK guidance and digital services


GOV.UK guidance for Get help with technology for remote education (opens in new tab) and the digital service Get help with technology (opens in new tab)
GOV.UK guidance for understanding Changes to the early years foundation stage (EYFS) framework (opens in new tab) and the digital information service Help for early years providers (opens in new tab)

Prototype non-transactional services using Whitehall
If you’re working on a non-transactional service at DfE, you must prototype a version of this on GOV.UK using Whitehall publisher. You must work with DCT when you do this.
GOV.UK defines a non-transactional service as something that allows users to either:


exchange information, money, permission, goods or services
submit personal information that results in a change of government record

Map out your service journeys
You should map out journeys so that you understand a user’s navigation through a service, including which interactions happen outside of the service as part of completing a journey.
A service journey map creates a timeline of the user’s touchpoints. They’re useful for understanding where a user interacts with content and the different elements of a service that the content needs to be consistent with.
Mapping out journeys helps you understand the user’s steps and helps to create a consistent and smooth user journey between GOV.UK guidance and a digital service.
Even if you’re not using GOV.UK to create a digital service, you should try to include any GOV.UK guidance content that supports the service as part of user testing.
Read about why we use journey maps in government (opens in new tab).
There are different methods for creating user journey maps, read about how to make a user journey map (opens in new tab).
Work with DCT on GOV.UK content
You must work with DCT on any content planned for GOV.UK. If you’ve been given access to a Whitehall account, you’ll usually be able to buddy up with a DCT content designer to support you through to publishing.
If you’ve not been given a buddy, you should still be able to work with DCT by:


getting an induction from DCT
getting a 2i check from a DCT content designer before publishing
getting the right clearances

Buddy up on GOV.UK journeys
Buddying up is where a DCT content designer supports a DfE content designer through DCT publishing processes and collaborates on content design decisions.
Buddying up should be done when content designers are:


working on content that’s planned to go on GOV.UK 
testing content in Whitehall as part of checking whether an information service should be built that does not sit on GOV.UK

Get an induction from DCT if you’re using Whitehall
Get an induction from DCT if you’ve been given a Whitehall publisher account to work on GOV.UK content to get an overview of DfE processes for GOV.UK content, including 2i checks and clearances.
Get a 2i from DCT
Before it’s published, all GOV.UK content needs to be checked by a DCT content designer to make sure it’s accessible and follows the GOV.UK style guide.
A 2i is a where a DCT content designer reviews the final draft of content in-line with the GOV.UK 2i checklist (opens in new tab) prior to publishing.
A 2i is different to a peer review. Peer reviews can be done at any stage of the drafting process. Content which will be published on GOV.UK should be peer reviewed by a content designer from the DCT.
Get the right clearances
DfE has strict clearance requirements for all GOV.UK publishing. This usually involves clearance from a Deputy Director (DD) and for high profile content, from strategic communications at DfE.
You may need to agree a publication date for certain content. This is to ensure the planning team know when the content will be published and if there are likely to be communication implications, such as media interest or questions.
Find out more on the intranet about DfE clearance processes for GOV.UK content (opens intranet page in new tab). If you do not have access to the DfE intranet, ask a colleague with access to get the information for you.
DCT will publish the content to GOV.UK after 2i checks have been completed and clearances have been confirmed.
Before you make a request for Whitehall publisher
Make sure you’ve spoken to DCT so they can help you decide if a request should be made and what kind of access is needed.
Content designers need to complete GDS training to use Whitehall. To ask for training, submit a request (opens intranet page in new tab). If you do not have access to the DfE intranet, ask a colleague with access to submit a request for you.
Other uses of Whitehall
Whitehall accounts also give individuals access to Integration, the test version of GOV.UK that can be used to prototype content. There are other ways to prototype content, so a Whitehall account cannot be given out just for this use.
To look at data and insight about GOV.UK you can request access to GOV.UK Sign-on. It’s different to a Whitehall publisher account but it still gives you access to:


content data - for analytics about GOV.UK 
feedex data - for user comments on content
